Abstract: The integration of adaptive control and reinforcement learning (RL) presents a promising avenue for developing systems that can autonomously adjust to dynamic environments while maintaining optimal performance. This paper explores the intersections between adaptive control and RL, focusing on their shared objectives of adaptation, optimality, stability, and robustness. Adaptive control traditionally emphasizes real-time parameter adjustment to maintain system stability and performance, while RL offers a framework for learning optimal policies through interaction with the environment. By leveraging the strengths of both fields, we propose a hybrid approach that enhances the adaptability and robustness of control systems. We discuss the theoretical underpinnings of adaptive control and RL, highlighting how concepts such as policy iteration and value function approximation can be integrated with adaptive mechanisms. Furthermore, we present case studies demonstrating the practical applications of this hybrid approach in complex, uncertain environments. Our findings suggest that combining adaptive control with RL not only improves system performance but also provides a robust framework for handling uncertainties, paving the way for more intelligent and autonomous control systems.
